required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Dietary Lipids, Energy Expenditure and Obesity Biomarkers
clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Dietary Lipid Modulation in Energy Expenditure, Body Composition, Obesity-related Biomarkers and Gene Expression of Peroxisome Proliferator-Activated Receptors Alpha and Gamma 2 in Adipose Tissue of Obese Women

lead_sponsor.agency: Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro

clinical_study.source: Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine whether the modulation of dietary lipids are effective in the treatment of obesity and comorbidities.

detailed_description.textblock: Obesity is a complex disease of multifactorial etiology and difficult to control. Among lifestyle changes proposed to the treatment of this disease and comorbidities, there is the modulation of dietary lipid composition. This study aimed to evaluate the effects of the modulation of fatty acid (FA) polyunsaturated (PUFA) and monounsaturated (MUFA) in energy expenditure (EE), weight loss, body composition, lipid and glycemic profile, free fatty acids (FFA), glycerol, adiponectin, leptin, blood pressure (BP), feeding behavior and expression of PPARα and PPARγ2 genes in adipose tissue (AT) of obese women. It was conducted a parallel, randomized, controlled, single-blind study with dietary intervention (DI) for 60 days, where 32 women with obesity classes I and II were distributed into three groups: G1 = diet rich in n-3 PUFA and n-6 (n = 10); G2 = MUFA-rich diet (n = 11); and G3 = control (n = 11). For G1 and G2 were prescribed normocaloric diets with similar macronutrient composition, varying only the type of lipids offered. In order to achieve the desired intake of unsaturated FA, both groups received individual portions of vegetable oils in the form of sachets, which were consumed for lunch and dinner (G1 = mix of virgin olive oil [VOO] and soybean oil [SO], overall of 35.2g to 52.8g / day; G2 = VOO, overall of 35.2g to 50.6 g / day), besides gelatin capsules (G1 = 2 g of fish oil / day; G2 = 1 capsule of 1g of SO / day). G3 was instructed to keep their eating habits and consuming placebos (1 sachet of 2g of SO and 1 capsule of 1g of SO / day).

primary_outcome.measure: Compare the effects of modulation of PUFA and MUFA in energy expenditure of obese women
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline energy expenditure at 2 months
primary_outcome.description: The energy expenditure was evaluated by indirect calorimetry (Vmax Encore 29 Systems®)

secondary_outcome.measure: Effects of modulation of PUFA and MUFA in body weight of obese women
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline loss of body weight at 2 months

secondary_outcome.measure: Effects of modulation of PUFA and MUFA in body composition of obese women
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline body composition at 2 months
secondary_outcome.description: The body composition was evaluated by electrical bioimpedance

secondary_outcome.measure: Effects of modulation of PUFA and MUFA in feeding behavior of obese women
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline feeding behavior at 2 months
secondary_outcome.description: Feeding behavior was evaluated by Three Factor Eating Questionnaire

secondary_outcome.measure: Effects of modulation of PUFA and MUFA in gene expression of obese women
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline gene expression at 2 months
secondary_outcome.description: Gene expression of PPARα and PPARγ2 in adipose tissue

secondary_outcome.measure: Effects of modulation of PUFA and MUFA in blood glucose of obese women
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline blood glucose at 2 months

secondary_outcome.measure: Effects of modulation of PUFA and MUFA in blood insulin of obese women
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline blood insulin at 2 months

secondary_outcome.measure: Effects of modulation of PUFA and MUFA in insulin resistance of obese women
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline insulin resistance at 2 months
secondary_outcome.description: Insulin resistance was evaluated by Homeostasis Model Assessment

secondary_outcome.measure: Effects of modulation of PUFA and MUFA in insulin sensitivity of obese women
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline insulin sensitivity at 2 months
secondary_outcome.description: Insulin resistance was evaluated by Quantitative Insulin Sensitivity Check Index

secondary_outcome.measure: Effects of modulation of PUFA and MUFA in total cholesterol and fractions of obese women
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline total cholesterol and fractions at 2 months
secondary_outcome.description: total cholesterol and fractions and triglycerides

secondary_outcome.measure: Effects of modulation of PUFA and MUFA in adiponectin of obese women
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline adiponectin at 2 months

secondary_outcome.measure: Effects of modulation of PUFA and MUFA in leptin of obese women
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline leptin at 2 months

secondary_outcome.measure: Effects of modulation of PUFA and MUFA in TNF alpha of obese women
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline TNF alpha at 2 months

secondary_outcome.measure: Effects of modulation of PUFA and MUFA in interleukin 6 of obese women
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline interleukin 6 at 2 months

arm_group.arm_group_label: Group 1 - diet rich in n-3 and n-6 PUFA
arm_group.description: Assigned intervention: The dietary intervention was conducted by 60 days. Were prescribed normocaloric diets with similar macronutrient composition, varying only the type of lipids offered. Group 1 received diet rich in n-3 and n-6 polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA). The volunteers were asked to consume daily a mixture of virgin olive oil and soybean oil, totaling 35.2g to 52.8g, and 2 g of fish oil.

Assigned intervention: The dietary intervention was conducted by 60 days. Were prescribed normocaloric diets with similar macronutrient composition, varying only the type of lipids offered. Group 2 received diet rich in monounsaturated fatty acids (MUFA). The volunteers were asked to consume daily virgin olive oil, totaling 35.2g to 50.6g, and 1 capsule of 1g of soybean oil.
Placebo group was instructed to keep their eating habits and consuming 1 sachet of 2g of soybean oil and 1 capsule of 1g of soybean oil by day.

intervention.intervention_name: Group 1 - diet rich in n-3 and n-6 PUFA
intervention.description: In order to achieve the desired intake of unsaturated FA, the group received individual portions of vegetable oils in the form of sachets, which were consumed for lunch and dinner, besides gelatin capsules, for 60 days.
intervention.arm_group_label: Group 1 - diet rich in n-3 and n-6 PUFA

intervention.description: In order to achieve the desired intake of unsaturated FA, the group received individual portions of vegetable oils in the form of sachets, which were consumed for lunch and dinner, besides gelatin capsules, for 60 days.
Placebo group was instructed to keep their eating habits and consuming placebo for 60 days.
